prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: vv114
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For VV114, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 2.8 Jy (Ao et al. to be submitted). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 7.0 mJy and 2.3 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.25 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.6 arcsec), leading to a signal-to-noise ratio of about 12 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 4 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 2.4 beams, which is a typical scale of the disks in ULIRGs (Downes & Solomon 1998). Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 5.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 2.6 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 4. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
The line free channels from all basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set, which will be used to estimate dust mass and star formation rate.
Three transitions, H2CO(3_03-2_02) at 218.22 GHz, H2CO(3_22-2_21) at 218.48 GHz, and H2CO(3_21-2_20) at 218.76 GHz will covered in one baseband. H2CO(3_22-2_21) may be blended by the emission from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) at 218.44 GHz. In the cases that show strong CH3OH(4_22-3_12) emission, only H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) will be used for data analysis. The predicted FWHM line width is about 320 km/s (233 MHz), which is comparable to the frequency differences (220 MHz and 280 MHz) between H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) and CH3OH(4_22-3_12)/H2CO(3_22-2_21). Assuming all H2CO transitions show a similar line profile, we are able to well separate H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) from H2CO(3_22-2_21)/CH3OH(4_22-3_12). Furthermore, the source is partially resolved, the blending effect of H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) will be less important. It will be difficult to separate H2CO(3_22-2_21) from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) if the latter is strong.
To reduce data rate, we will average the spectra by a factor of 16. The spectral resolution of about 10 km/s is good enough for our scientific goals.
We request the compact array configuration to obtain the best sensitivity. We set a LAS size of 5 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n3256
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 3256, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 26 Jy (Ao et al. to be submitted). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 65 mJy and 22 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.6 arcsec), leading to a signal-to-noise ratio of about 15 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 5 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 11 beams, which is a typical scale of the disks in ULIRGs (Downes & Solomon 1998). Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 6.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 15 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 3.4. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
The line free channels from all basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set, which will be used to estimate dust mass and star formation rate.
Three transitions, H2CO(3_03-2_02) at 218.22 GHz, H2CO(3_22-2_21) at 218.48 GHz, and H2CO(3_21-2_20) at 218.76 GHz will covered in one baseband. H2CO(3_22-2_21) may be blended by the emission from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) at 218.44 GHz. In the cases that show strong CH3OH(4_22-3_12) emission, only H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) will be used for data analysis. The predicted FWHM line width is about 200 km/s (146 MHz), which is smaller than the frequency differences (220 MHz and 280 MHz) between H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) and CH3OH(4_22-3_12)/H2CO(3_22-2_21). Assuming all H2CO transitions show a similar line profile, we are able to well separate H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) from H2CO(3_22-2_21)/CH3OH(4_22-3_12). Furthermore, the source is well resolved, thus the blending effect between H2CO(3_22-2_21) and CH3OH(4_22-3_12) may be not important and can be separated.
To reduce data rate, we will average the spectra by a factor of 16. The spectral resolution of about 10 km/s is good enough for our scientific goals.
We request the compact array configuration to obtain the best sensitivity. We set a LAS size of 10.6 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: f18293
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For IRAS F18293-3413, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 8 Jy (Ao et al. to be submitted). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 20 mJy and 6.7 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a signal-to-noise ratio of about 17 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 6 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 3 beams, which is a typical scale of the disks in ULIRGs (Downes & Solomon 1998). Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 7.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 4.2 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 3.5. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
The line free channels from all basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set, which will be used to estimate dust mass and star formation rate.
Three transitions, H2CO(3_03-2_02) at 218.22 GHz, H2CO(3_22-2_21) at 218.48 GHz, and H2CO(3_21-2_20) at 218.76 GHz will covered in one baseband. H2CO(3_22-2_21) may be blended by the emission from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) at 218.44 GHz. In the cases that show strong CH3OH(4_22-3_12) emission, only H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) will be used for data analysis. The predicted FWHM line width is about 310 km/s (226 MHz), which is comparable to the frequency differences (220 MHz and 280 MHz) between H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) and CH3OH(4_22-3_12)/H2CO(3_22-2_21). Assuming all H2CO transitions show a similar line profile, we are able to well separate H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) from H2CO(3_22-2_21)/CH3OH(4_22-3_12).Furthermore, the source is partially resolved, the blending effect of H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) will be less important. It will be difficult to separate H2CO(3_22-2_21) from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) if the latter is strong.
To reduce data rate, we will average the spectra by a factor of 16. The spectral resolution of about 10 km/s is good enough for our scientific goals.
We request the compact array configuration to obtain the best sensitivity. We set a LAS size of 5.4 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n7130
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: search for h2co transition lines at 218 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the IRAM 30m, the CO(2-1)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) line ratios (Mao et al. 2000; Muehle et al. 2007) in M~82 are found to be 400 and 3, respectively. We will adopt the line ratios in M82 to estimate the fluxes of H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20).
For NGC 7130, the observed CO(2-1) flux is 12 Jy (Ao et al. to be submitted). Therefore, the expected H2CO(3_03-2_02) and H2CO(3_21-2_20) are 30 mJy and 10 mJy, respectively. We would like to request for a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy at velocity resolution of 50 km/s in the compact configuration for the ALMA band 6 (the corresponding angular resolution is about 1.7 arcsec), leading to a signal-to-noise ratio of about 20 for H2CO(3_03-2_02) and 7 for H2CO(3_21-2_20), respectively, if the emission is homogeneously distributed over a region of 1 kpc, i.e., 3.7 beams, which is a typical scale of the disks in ULIRGs (Downes & Solomon 1998). Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and H(30)alpha will be observed simultaneously together with H2CO.
CO(2-1) is 400 times stronger than H2CO(3_03-2_02) (this ratio is what we assumed to estimate the H2CO fluxes). It is no doubt that CO(2-1) can be detected above a signal-to-noise ratio above 400.
We have carried out a H2CO survey in the CMZ (Ao et al. 2013), and SiO(5-4) has been measured in the same observations. The median SiO(5-4)/H2CO(3_03-2_02) line ratio is about 0.4. Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the signal-to-noise ratio for SiO(5-4) is about 8.
The recombination line, H(30)alpha, can be related with the SFR by S*dv=0.445*SFR/(100 Msun/yr)*(D/100Mpc)^(-2)*(nu/350 GHz)^(-1) Jy km/s (Scoville & Murchikova 2013) if the line emission is contributed from star formation. The SFRs can be dervied from far-infrared luminosities via SFR =1.7 L_FIR(10^10 Lsun) Msun/yr (Kennicutt 1998). Adopting the same assumptions and requested sensitivity for estimating H2CO fluxes, the H(30)alpha flux will be 4.2 mJy and the signal-to-noise ratio is about 3.3. Note that the emission is very likely distributed over a smaller region at a specified velocity channel, leading higher signal-to-noise ratios.
The line free channels from all basebands will be used to generate a continuum data set, which will be used to estimate dust mass and star formation rate.
Three transitions, H2CO(3_03-2_02) at 218.22 GHz, H2CO(3_22-2_21) at 218.48 GHz, and H2CO(3_21-2_20) at 218.76 GHz will covered in one baseband. H2CO(3_22-2_21) may be blended by the emission from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) at 218.44 GHz. The predicted FWHM line width is about 130 km/s (95 MHz), which is much smaller than the frequency differences (220 MHz and 280 MHz) between H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) and CH3OH(4_22-3_12)/H2CO(3_22-2_21). In this case, we can easily separate H2CO(3_03-2_02)/H2CO(3_21-2_20) from H2CO(3_22-2_21)/CH3OH(4_22-3_12). Furthermore, the source is partially resolved, the blending effect of H2CO(3_22-2_21)/CH3OH(4_22-3_12) will be less important. Assuming all H2CO transitions show a similar line profile, we are able to separate H2CO(3_22-2_21) from CH3OH(4_22-3_12) even if the latter is strong.
To reduce data rate, we will average the spectra by a factor of 16. The spectral resolution of about 10 km/s is good enough for our scientific goals.
We request the compact array configuration to obtain the best sensitivity. We set a LAS size of 6.1 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of 2 kpc.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous infrared galaxies, LIRGs, are characterized by high far infrared luminosities from active galactic nuclei and extreme starbursts that are very compact with the bulk of their molecular gas in a very dense phase. Recent evidence points to very elevated cosmic-ray (CR) energy densities and/or extreme turbulence rather than far-UV/optical radiation fields predominantly heating their massive dense gas reservoirs. If this is indeed the case, it will lead to fundamental consequences for all SF events with high star formation rate (SFR) densities taking place in the local or distant Universe, as it will likely alter the initial conditions of star formation and perhaps even the stellar initial mass function (IMF) in a systematic way. Formaldehyde (H2CO) is an excellent tracer of molecular gas to study gas excitation as demonstrated in Galactic studies. We therefore propose to observe the transition lines of H2CO at 218 GHz towards a sample of LIRGs at different evolutionary stages to determine their gas kinetic temperature.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
